questions.text: What are the muscles attached to the marked area ?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The marked area is the mandibular ramus, which gives attachment to the masseter (lateral surface), temporalis (coronoid process), and medial and lateral pterygoids (medial surface and pterygoid fovea).

  • The mandible, particularly the ramus and its processes, serves as an attachment site for several muscles of mastication. The four key muscles attached to it:
    • Masseter
      • Origin: Zygomatic arch
      • Insertion: Lateral surface of the ramus and angle of the mandible
    • Temporalis
      • Origin: Temporal fossa
      • Insertion: Coronoid process and anterior border of ramus
    • Medial pterygoid
      • Origin: Medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate
      • Insertion: Medial surface of ramus and angle (mirroring masseter)
    • Lateral pterygoid
      • Insertion: Pterygoid fovea on neck of mandible, capsule and disc of TMJ

Explanation of other options:

Buccinator, Temporalis, Masseter (Option A) : Buccinator attaches to the alveolar processes of maxilla and mandible and not to the ramus.

Two Pterygoids, Temporalis, Buccinator (Option C) : Buccinator is not attached to the ramus.

Lateral Pterygoid, Buccinator, Masseter (Option D) : Buccinator again incorrectly included; temporalis is missing despite inserting into coronoid.

questions.text: The marked ligament shown below arises and runs along ?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The marked structure connects the malleus (middle ear ossicle) to the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), identifying it as the discomalleolar ligament.

  • The discomalleolar ligament (also known as Pinto's ligament) is an embryological remnant of Meckel's cartilage. It:
    • Originates from the malleus in the middle ear
    • Passes through the petrotympanic fissure
    • Inserts into the posterior part of the articular disc and capsule of the TMJ
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Because of this connection, disorders of the TMJ (e.g. inflammation or disc displacement) can cause referred otologic symptoms like ear pain, tinnitus, or fullness, despite a normal ear exam.
    • It thus seems that otic symptoms (tinnitus, otalgia (ear pain), dizziness and hypoacusis) corresponding to altered ossicular spatial relationships (such as conductive middle ear pathologies) can also be produced from masticatory system pathologies.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior malleolar ligament (Option A) : Connects the malleus to the anterior wall of the middle ear cavity, not the TMJ.

Stylomandibular ligament (Option B) : Runs from the styloid process to the angle of the mandible and does not pass through the petrotympanic fissure or related to the middle ear.

Temporomandibular ligament (Option D) : Reinforces the lateral aspect of the TMJ capsule. It does not involve the middle ear.

choices.text: A - Deep auricular artery B- Superficial temporal artery
A- Anterior tympanic artery B- Subclavian artery
A - Superficial temporal artery B - Deep auricular artery
A - Subclavian artery B - Deep auricular artery

questions.text: Identify marked arteries as A and B in relation with blood supply of temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deep auricular artery (A) enters the external acoustic meatus supplying the posterior TMJ, while the superficial temporal artery (B) ascends anterior to the ear to supply the lateral TMJ region.

  • The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) receives its arterial supply primarily from branches of the external carotid artery, including:
    • Superficial temporal artery (Branch of external carotid)
      • Ascends in front of the ear, superficial to the zygomatic arch
      • Supplies lateral aspect of the TMJ and adjacent muscles
    • Deep auricular artery (Branch of maxillary artery, which itself is a terminal branch of external carotid)
      • Enters the external acoustic meatus
      • Supplies the posterior part of the TMJ, external acoustic meatus, and tympanic membrane
    • Other arteries contributing to TMJ supply:
      • Anterior tympanic artery (another branch of maxillary): contributes via adjacent structures
      • Masseteric and middle meningeal arteries (indirectly through surrounding muscles)
    • Together, these vessels ensure rich anastomotic supply to the TMJ capsule, articular disc, and surrounding musculature.

Explanation of other options:

A - Anterior tympanic artery, B - Subclavian artery (Option B) : Anterior tympanic is small and not the main posterior supplier; subclavian artery doesn't supply TMJ.

A - Superficial temporal artery, B - Deep auricular artery (Option C) : Reversed identification of the arteries; A is posterior, which matches deep auricular, not superficial temporal.

A - Subclavian artery, B - Deep auricular artery (Option D) : Subclavian does not directly supply TMJ

choices.text: The TMJ is a pivot joint innervated by the facial nerve
The TMJ is a hinge joint supplied by the superior thyroid artery
The TMJ is a condyloid joint primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve
The TMJ is a condyloid joint supplied by the ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the temporomandibular joint (TMJ)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The TMJ is a modified condyloid synovial joint and is sensory innervated chiefly by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

  • The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is classified as a modified condyloid synovial joint because it allows movement in multiple planes ; hinge-like depression/elevation and gliding (protrusion/retraction and lateral excursion).
  • It is primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the posterior division of V3 (mandibular nerve), with minor contributions from the masseteric nerve.
  • The blood supply of TMJ is:
    • Main supply: Maxillary and superficial temporal arteries.
    • Minor contributors: Middle meningeal, anterior tympanic, and masseteric arteries.

questions.text: Which compartment of TMJ (Temporomandibular joint) allows the following movements?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows Rotational movement and the inferior compartment allows rotational movements.

The superior compartment allows translational movements to occur at the joint. These movements include the:

  • Protrusion- the anterior movement of the mandible.
  • Retraction- the posterior movement of the mandible.
  • Left and right lateral deviation of the mandible - this usually refers to the acts of grinding and chewing.

The inferior compartment allows rotational movements. More specifically, rotation occurs between the superior surface of the condyle and the inferior surface of the articular disc. Rotational movement of the mandible can occur in all three planes: horizontal, frontal (vertical), and sagittal. These movements include the:

  • Depression- a movement of opening the mouth. This movement is mostly caused by gravity, however, if there is resistance, then muscles facilitate this movement.
  • Elevation- a strong movement of closing the mouth.

In most cases, both rotation and translation occur simultaneously. This results in complex movements that allow people to chew and talk.

choices.text: Elevation and protrusion of the mandible
Depression and protrusion of the mandible
Retraction and protrusion of the mandible
Depression and elevation of the mandible

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked below ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscle shown in the image is medial pterygoid. The function of it is elevation and protrusion of the mandible

  • The medial pterygoid muscle is a thick rectangular muscle with a superficial head and a deep head.
  • The deep head of the medial pterygoid is larger than the superficial head.
  • The medial pterygoid muscle functions to assist with elevation and protrusion of the mandible.
  • It also assists the lateral pterygoid muscle with side to side mandibular motion to help with the grinding of food.

questions.text: Identify the marked muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscle is lateral pterygoid.

  • The lateral pterygoid is a short, thick muscle with two heads. The upper and lower head.
  • The lateral pterygoid muscle functions as the sole muscle of mastication to cause depression of the mandible.
  • This being the case, depression of the mandible is largely the result of gravity.
  • It also assists with protrusion and side to side movement of the mandible.

choices.text: A - Elevation and retraction of mandible B - Protrusion C - Elevation D - Elevation and side to side movements of mandible
A - Elevation B - Protrusion C - Elevation and side to side movements of mandible D - Elevation and retraction of mandible
A - Elevation and side to side movements of mandible B - Protrusion C - Elevation and retraction of mandible D - Elevation
A - Protrusion B - Elevation and retraction of mandible C - Elevation and side to side movements of mandible D - Elevation

questions.text: Identify the functions of the muscles marked below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscles marked are:

A - Temporalis

B - Lateral pterygoid

C - Masseter

D - Medial pterygoid

The functions are elevation and retraction of mandible , protrusion , elevation , elevation and side to side movements of mandible respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles aids in forceful expulsion of air from the mouth?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Buccinator assists in the forceful expulsion of air from the mouth. Buccinator is marked as D in the image

  • The buccinator forms the muscular component of the cheek.
  • It is in the space between the mandible and the maxilla, deep to the other facial muscles in the area.
  • Origin:
    • From the alveolar processes of:
      • Maxilla (opposite molar teeth)
      • Mandible (opposite molar teeth)
    • Also from the pterygomandibular raphe
  • Insertion:
    • Blends with fibers of the orbicularis oris at the angle of the mouth (modiolus)
  • Innervation:
    • Buccal branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)
  • Blood Supply:
    • Primarily by facial artery and buccal artery (branch of maxillary artery)
  • Function:
    • Compresses the cheek against the teeth (e.g. blowing, sucking, keeping food between occlusal surfaces while chewing)
    • Assists in articulation and facial expressions (but not a muscle of mastication)
